page.title: 03Roots of East Hagbourne
page.content: East Hagbourne probably dates from Roman times but the first written record of the name is in a charter of King Alfred which refers to "Hacca Burn" and "Hacca Broc". The name later changed to East Hachbourne when mentioned in the Domesday Book. In 1659 a fire destroyed most of the Mediaeval settlement along Main Road. In the early 1840's the common grazing right of the villagers was lost and land enclosed. In the ninteenth century the London to Bristol railway line cut across East Hagbourne marsh, and a branch line to Newbury divided East and West Hagbourne permanently. Today the old Newbury Branch is a public footpath but still represents a barrier to further development of Didcot which might eventually swallow up East Hagbourne.
